content.title: Identifying Partially Observed Causal Models from Heterogeneous/Nonstationary Data
content.abstract: Estimating causal structure in the presence of latent variables is an important yet challenging problem. Recent works have shown that distributional constraints, such as rank deficiency constraints of the covariance matrices, can be exploited to recover the underlying causal structure involving latent variables. However, real-world data often exhibit heterogeneity/nonstationarity, which pose challenges to existing methods. In this work, we develop a principled approach for identifying the structure of partially observed linear causal models from heterogenous/nonstationary data. We first formulate a class of heterogenous/nonstationary, partially observed linear causal models and prove that their distributional constraints are equivalent to those in the homogeneous case. Building on this, we propose a novel rank deficiency test that can efficiently handle heterogenous/nonstationary data, and further establish identifiability results for recovering the causal structure involving latent variables. We also provide a method to identify which variables exhibit distribution shifts, i.e., whose causal mechanisms vary across domains. Experiments on simulated and real-world data validate our theoretical findings and the effectiveness of our method.

summary.value:
This paper proposes a rank-based test for identifying causal structures from nonstationary data in the presence of latent variables. The method is motivated by two key propositions:

1. The set of equality constraints in POLCMs is identical to that in nonstationary POLCMs (Theorem 1).
2. The rank of the conditional covariance matrix corresponds to the (t)-separation set.

strengths.value: The paper considered in the paper is interesting. The paper is well organized and written.

weaknesses.value:
This paper has several conceptual, theoretical, and empirical flaws.

First, although the paper proposes a method to identify causal structures from nonstationary POLCMs, the proposed algorithm is only applicable under Gaussian assumptions. This imposes strong restrictions on the functions (h) and (g), yet the authors do not discuss under what conditions these functions satisfy the Gaussian constraint.

Second, the proof of Theorem 4 is incorrect. It appears to be a direct application of Theorem 1 without additional justification. Moreover, since the proposed algorithm relies on Gaussianity, it may fail to correctly test (t)-separation (even under rank faithfulness) for non-Gaussian distributions within nonstationary POLCMs.

Third, there are conceptual errors in some claims. For instance, lines 232–233 on page 5 state that “in this case, only the second-order information can be used.” This is inaccurate, as uncorrelatedness does not imply independence. Furthermore, numerous nonparametric conditional independence (CI) testing methods—such as kernel-based approaches—can go beyond simple correlation testing.

Lastly, the empirical validation is not convincing. The paper does not report standard evaluation metrics such as precision and recall. In addition, the authors fail to specify the functional forms of (h) and (g), which is crucial because even if (\delta) and (\epsilon) are Gaussian, the transformations may induce non-Gaussianity in (X). It would be insightful to evaluate the proposed method’s performance in such cases.

summary.value: The paper studies causal discovery with latent variables under heterogeneous/nonstationary settings. It defines two covariance sets: $\Theta(G)$, all observed covariances generated by a homogeneous linear SEM with (possibly latent) graph; and $\Phi(G)$, all conditional covariances generated by a nonstationary version of the model (mechanisms vary across domains $T$. The main theoretical result shows $\Theta(G) = \Phi(G)$, which allows direct generalization of causal discovery methods to nonstationary settings conditioned on a domain. Building on this, the authors propose a likelihood-ratio rank test that aggregates information across domains and a two-phase algorithm. Synthetic and one real dataset illustrate improved structure recovery over baselines and demonstrate the new test’s type I/II behavior.

strengths.value:
1. The paper is mostly self-contained and well-explained.
2. The paper provides solid definitions and theoretical results, which justify the extension of classic results to the nonstationary case.
3. The experiments validate type-I control and power of the rank test, showing gains in structure recovery when upgrading Phase 1 methods. The end-to-end results clearly show the efficiency of the algorithm.

weaknesses.value:
1. Although the paper tackles the challenging heterogeneous setting, many of its results are direct extensions of classic ones, which undermines its technical novelty.

   $\cdot$ Theorem 1,2 are simply based on the trek algebra and conditional independence.

   $\cdot$ The LRT in Theorem 3 is essentially a stratified version of the classical CCA-based rank test (Anderson/Muirhead).

2. While the author has acknowledged the limitation of Gaussianity in using the rank test, its robustness remains unclear to me. For example, in Figure 11, the author tested its performance under non-Gaussian noise, but which non-Gaussian noise was used? How would the results be affected in terms of causal discovery from end-to-end? Would non-Gaussian noise also affect phase 2? I suggest the author provide more details on this point.

3. The description of phase 2 is not as clear as the other parts of the paper. It was split into different sections, which makes it hard to follow. A pseudo-code or a more structured description would be helpful.

4. I found some of the experimental settings insufficient. For example, the number of domains is limited to 10, and the number of samples seems to be the same across the domains. However, it was stated that the motivation of the new rank test is to deal with cases with a large number of domains and imbalanced sample sizes. Therefore, experiments with a larger number of domains and different sample sizes should be included.

summary.value: The paper discusses causal discovery with heterogenous data. In particular, they consider linear models with time-varying coefficients and noise variance, and show that the constraints (equality/inequality) constraints induced by these models are derived from the constraints over the covariance matrix in the homogenous model which is established in the literature. They also consider structure identification among latent variables under faithfulness (A2), multiple pure measurements, and invariant measurement (A1) assumptions.

strengths.value: The theoretical results are well presented, and the manuscript is mostly self-contained despite the page-limit.

weaknesses.value:
The experiments lack sufficient comparison with the existing work. If there is such limited number of comparable existing work, then the problem setting needs more motivation and discussion using examples real or synthetic. 

There is a number of existing work on causal discovery in partially observed linear models. It is useful to the reader why/how heterogeneity needs special treatment, especially when the theoretical results suggest that constraints imposed by heterogenous model are quite similar to the homogenous model.

summary.value: The paper considers latent-variable causal discovery when data are heterogeneous/nonstationary across domains. It formalizes Nonstationary POLCMs (partially observed linear causal models) and proves an equivalence between the homogeneous covariance constraints and the conditional (on domain $T$) covariance constraints in the nonstationary case (Theorem 1), implying that equality-constraint methods for static data can be ``upgraded'' by replacing unconditional with conditional tests. Building on this, the authors relate the rank of conditional cross-covariances to $t$-separation (Theorem 2), and develop a likelihood-ratio test for the rank of $\Sigma_{A,B\mid T}$ that aggregates information across all domains (Theorem 3). They then propose LCD-NOD, a two-phase procedure: Phase 1 adapts existing equality-constraint methods (e.g., PC, FOFC, RLCD) to nonstationary data via the new rank test; Phase 2 identifies which variables (observed or latent) are directly affected by nonstationarity by comparing parameters across domains in a nonstationary one-factor model setting (Theorem 5).

strengths.value:
- Theorem 1 and Corollary 1 formalize that structure-induced equality (and inequality) constraints transfer to the nonstationary case by conditioning on $T$.
- Theorem 2 extends trek-separation characterizations to conditional covariances, enabling the use of rank constraints with domain shifts.
- For a nonstationary one-factor model, the paper gives parameter identification (up to scaling) per domain.

weaknesses.value:
- As mentioned by the authors, the conditional rank assumes joint Gaussianity given T to derive the null distribution.
- Change-localization is developed for the one-factor model with additional assumptions, such as at least one invariant measurement coefficient per latent (Assumption A.1) or each observed variable is a "pure measurement" of exactly one latent.

questions.value:
- About Theorem 1, in the modelling, it is assumed that g and H are independent given $T$. Could you provide a counterexample that the relation between $\Theta(\mathcal{G})=\Phi(\mathcal{G})$ fails if this assumption does not hold?

- In LIT (Yang et al., 2024), they provided an identifiability result up to what extent we can determine the locations of changes in the presence of latent confounding. Could you compare your result with that identifiability result, assuming that only the distributions of exogenous noises are changing across the environments?

- Is there a path to handle multi-factor measurement models or cases with no pure measurements?
